title: Climate Impact Report Reveals 80,000 Deaths & 1.3 Billion Affected in India - Deccan Herald
article_text:
New Delhi: Disasters over the past three decades, with nearly 430 extreme weather events killing more than 80,000 people, according to a new report.
The Climate Risk Index (CRI) 2026 released by the environment think tank Germanwatch at COP30 in Belem, Brazil, on Tuesday said climate disasters affected 1.3 billion people and caused economic losses worth almost USD 170 billion from 1995 to 2024.
The report said the country's losses stemmed largely from repeated floods, cyclones, droughts and heat waves that have intensified with global warming.
Events such as the 1998 Gujarat cyclone, the 1999 Odisha super cyclone, the 2013 Uttarakhand floods and recent deadly heat waves are among those that contributed to India's high ranking on the index, it said.
The report said India's situation represents a "continuous threat" rather than isolated disasters, as recurring weather extremes have steadily eroded development gains and undermined livelihoods.
It said that India's vast population and high exposure to monsoon variability make it particularly vulnerable, with extreme events often affecting millions each year.
In 2024 alone, India was hit by heavy monsoon rains and flash floods that impacted more than eight million people, especially in Gujarat, Maharashtra and Tripura, the report said.
It said floods and storms were the most damaging events globally last year, accounting for nearly half of all people affected and inflicting billions in losses.
Globally, Germanwatch said more than 9,700 extreme weather events between 1995 and 2024 claimed over 8.3 lakh lives, affected nearly 5.7 billion people and caused direct economic damage of around USD 4.5 trillion.
Dominica was the most-affected country in the past three decades, followed by Myanmar, Honduras, Libya, Haiti, Grenada, Philippines, Nicaragua, India and Bahamas.
Developing countries, the think tank said, remained disproportionately affected due to lower coping capacity and limited resources for adaptation.
The report stressed that while El Niño conditions influenced weather patterns in 2024, human-induced climate change played a decisive role in intensifying heat waves, storms and floods worldwide.
Scientific studies cited in the report found that climate change made many of these events more likely and more severe, including prolonged spells of dangerous heat that affected billions.
The report warned that such frequent disasters are becoming the "new normal" for many developing nations, including India, demanding urgent and well-funded adaptation measures.
It said repeated losses strain public finances and weaken the ability of communities to recover, pushing many deeper into poverty.
Germanwatch said that the findings of the Climate Risk Index should be seen as a reminder for global leaders meeting at COP30 to close the gap in climate finance and accelerate efforts to reduce emissions and strengthen resilience.
It said the growing economic and human costs underline the need for countries like India to prioritise adaptation planning, early warning systems and the protection of vulnerable groups.
The think tank also acknowledged data limitations in the analysis, noting that some countries, particularly in the Global South, may be underrepresented due to incomplete reporting.

title: Monsoon Alert – Snowfall Increases Chill, Heavy Rain Warning Issued for These States - Times Bull
article_text:
Monsoon Forecast – The weather is changing across much of India. Snowfall in many parts of the mountains has significantly increased the cold in the plains. Winter has also begun in Uttar Pradesh, Haryana, and Bihar, with temperatures dropping. People have begun wearing warm clothing in the morning and evening.

Dense fog has enveloped many areas of Delhi NCR and western Uttar Pradesh since morning, causing difficulties for pedestrians. A cold wave-like cold in the northeastern states is making things feel cool.

Pollution levels in Delhi are now returning to normal, making breathing easier for people. The Indian Meteorological Department has predicted rain in several states within the next 24 hours. Details about the expected weather can be found below.

Heavy Rain Alert in These States

The Indian Meteorological Department has issued an alert for heavy rain in some states. According to the IMD, heavy rain is expected in several areas of Tamil Nadu, Kerala, and Karnataka. An alert has been issued for moderate rain with thunderstorms in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands and Lakshadweep.

Light rain is possible at isolated places in Maharashtra, Goa, and Telangana. Cold weather is expected to increase in Bihar, Jharkhand, and Madhya Pradesh. Snowfall is possible at isolated places in Himachal Pradesh and Uttarakhand. Temperatures are also expected to drop in Jammu and Kashmir due to snowfall at several locations.

Weather in Delhi NCR

According to the Meteorological Department, the cold has increased in Delhi NCR, with fog prevailing in the atmosphere. The IMD predicts the minimum temperature will be 4.1 degrees Celsius below normal, or up to 10 degrees Celsius. The maximum temperature is expected to be 27 to 28 degrees Celsius. The AQI was recorded at 423, which is considered in the severe category.

Strict anti-pollution measures have been implemented under the third phase of GRAP. According to the PCB, the average air quality index has reached 423. An AQI between zero and 50 is considered very good. Between 51 and 100 is satisfactory. Between 101 and 200 is moderate. Between 201 and 300, the environment becomes poor; between 301 and 400, it becomes very poor, and between 401 and 500, it becomes severe.

Possibility of snowfall here

According to the IMD, there is no possibility of any Western Disturbance becoming active in the weather for the next 10 days. This has led to clear weather in the mountains. Dense fog may prevail in the mornings and evenings, along with cold winds.

Snowfall is expected in the higher reaches of Gulmarg, Sonamarg, and Pahalgam in Jammu and Kashmir. As soon as snowfall occurs, the number of tourists to these places starts increasing. These areas are considered very good for tourists when snowfall increases annually.
